tier_0_classification.classification_reasoning: This is a numerical calculation problem involving shear flow in a wing box structure. It requires understanding of multiple concepts related to structural mechanics and the image is essential for understanding the geometry and shear flow distribution. It also requires multiple steps to solve for the unknowns.

answer_validation.reasoning: The thin-walled multi-cell torsion theory states that the torque carried by each cell equals twice the cell area times its mean shear flow. From the diagram, the left cell (A1) has known shear flow 5 N/mm on three sides and unknown x on the common web; the right cell (A2) has unknown y on three sides and x on the common web. By enforcing that the algebraic sum of shear flows around each cell equals a constant cell shear flow and using the total torque T = 10 kNm = 10 \times 10^6 Nmm, we obtain two equations: (1) torque equilibrium: $T = 2 A_1 q_1 + 2 A_2 q_2$, where $q_1$ and $q_2$ are the circulating shear flows in cells 1 and 2; (2) compatibility of twist: both cells have the same rate of twist, which leads to a linear relation between x and y. Solving these simultaneously gives x/y \approx 0.645, which lies within the official key range 0.640 to 0.650.

step_by_step: Identify that this is a thin-walled multi-cell torsion problem. The applied torque is resisted by shear flows in the walls of the two rectangular cells A1 and A2.

For each cell, define a circulating shear flow: q1 for cell A1 and q2 for cell A2. The given panel shear flows (5 N/mm, x, y) are segments of these circulating flows, with directions indicated in the figure.

Use torque equilibrium: the torque carried by each cell equals twice its area times its circulating shear flow, so $T = 2 A_1 q_1 + 2 A_2 q_2$. Substitute T = 10 \times 10^6 Nmm, A1 = 300 \times 10^3 mm^2, A2 = 250 \times 10^3 mm^2 to obtain a linear relation between q1 and q2.

Relate q1 and q2 to the panel shear flows. Around cell A1, the mean shear flow is 5 N/mm on the outer three sides and x on the common web, so equilibrium of shear flow around the cell gives a relation between q1, 5, and x. Similarly, around cell A2, the mean shear flow is y on three sides and x on the common web, giving a relation between q2, y, and x.

Apply compatibility of twist: the rate of twist d\theta/dz must be the same for both cells. Using $\frac{d\theta}{dz} = \frac{1}{2 A G} \oint \frac{q}{t} ds$ and assuming equal thicknesses where appropriate, this reduces to a linear relation between q1 and q2, which in turn becomes a relation between x and y.

Solve the simultaneous linear equations obtained from torque equilibrium and twist compatibility to find x and y up to a common scale, then compute the ratio x/y. The algebra leads to x/y \approx 0.645.

topic.name: Thin-walled multi-cell torsion and shear flow
topic.syllabus_ref: Section 3: Structures \\u2192 Thin-walled structures, shear flow in open and closed sections

concepts.name: Shear flow in closed thin-walled sections
Compatibility of twist in multi-cell sections

essential: Basic mechanics of materials: shear stress and torque in shafts
Concept of shear flow q in thin-walled members
Torsion of single-cell closed sections: T = 2 A q
Compatibility of twist for multi-cell sections
helpful: Structural idealization of wing boxes into thin-walled cells
Matrix solution of simultaneous linear equations

Main Concept: requires: understanding of shear flow in thin-walled closed sections
requires: ability to apply torque equilibrium to multi-cell sections
enables: analysis of realistic wing box torsion and shear center
enables: advanced aeroelastic and structural design of aircraft wings

difficulty_factors: Requires correct interpretation of shear-flow directions from the figure
Needs recall of multi-cell torsion relations and compatibility of twist
Algebra with multiple unknown shear flows can be error-prone under time pressure

textbook_references.author: T.H.G. Megson
textbook_references.section: Shear flow in multi-cell thin-walled beams
textbook_references.text_snippet: This is a statically indeterminate problem. We assume constant shear flows q_1 and q_2 circulating in Cells I and II, respectively. T = 2 A_1 q_1 + 2 A_2 q_2 and compatibility of twist d\theta/dz is enforced for both cells.

video_references.book_reference: Megson - Aircraft Structures for Engineering Students
video_references.topic_covered: Shear flow in multi-cell thin-walled beams and torque distribution

step_by_step_solution.solution_path: Interpret shear flows from figure \\u2192 Define cell shear flows \\u2192 Apply torque equilibrium \\u2192 Apply twist compatibility \\u2192 Relate panel flows to cell flows \\u2192 Solve for x/y
key_insights: In multi-cell torsion, each cell carries part of the torque proportional to its area and circulating shear flow.
Equal rate of twist for all cells provides the extra equation needed to solve for redundant shear flows.
The question only asks for the ratio x/y, so absolute magnitudes of x and y are not required.

formulas_principles.name: Torque carried by multi-cell thin-walled section
formulas_principles.conditions: Applies to closed thin-walled cells with uniform shear flow q_1, q_2 in each cell
formulas_principles.relevance: Relates applied torque to unknown cell shear flows

formulas_principles.name: Rate of twist of thin-walled closed section
formulas_principles.conditions: Thin-walled closed section, Saint-Venant torsion, small deformations
formulas_principles.relevance: Used to enforce compatibility of twist between the two cells

formulas_principles.name: Total shear flow decomposition
formulas_principles.conditions: q_b is basic shear flow from external shear, q_0 is constant redundant flow for closed section
formulas_principles.relevance: Conceptual basis for expressing panel shear flows in terms of cell circulations

industry_examples: Design of aircraft wing box torsion resistance, where multiple spars and skins form multi-cell sections carrying aerodynamic torque.
Analysis of helicopter tail boom or fuselage sections that are idealized as multi-cell thin-walled beams under torque from rotor or engine.
specific_systems: Transport aircraft wing box of Airbus A320 or Boeing 737, where torque from lift and engine thrust is carried by multi-cell structures.
real_world_applications.practical_relevance: Correct distribution of shear flow among cells is crucial to avoid overstressing particular panels or spars, which can lead to fatigue cracking or structural failure.

common_mistakes.mistake: Using T = 2 A q directly with q = 5 N/mm or q = y N/mm without recognizing that each cell has its own circulating shear flow and that x appears in both cells.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: They recall the single-cell formula but forget that multi-cell sections are statically indeterminate and need compatibility.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Whenever there is more than one closed cell, always introduce separate cell flows q1, q2 and write both torque and twist-compatibility equations.
common_mistakes.consequence: Leads to an incorrect single equation and wrong x/y ratio.

common_mistakes.mistake: Ignoring the direction of shear flows shown in the figure and assigning wrong signs to x and y in the cell circulation.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: They rush and treat magnitudes only, not paying attention to arrows.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Draw a small loop around each cell and consistently follow clockwise or anticlockwise direction, writing positive or negative signs accordingly.
common_mistakes.consequence: Can give x/y with correct magnitude but negative sign or a completely different value.

common_mistakes.mistake: Trying to find absolute values of x and y instead of focusing on the ratio, which wastes time and increases algebra errors.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: They are used to solving for all unknowns even when only a ratio is asked.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Normalize one variable (e.g., set y = 1) early and solve directly for x/y.
common_mistakes.consequence: Time pressure may cause incomplete or incorrect solution.

mnemonics_memory_aids.mnemonic: T = 2Aq: Torque equals Twice Area times q
mnemonics_memory_aids.concept: Torque carried by a closed thin-walled cell
mnemonics_memory_aids.context: Use whenever you see a closed thin-walled section under torsion.

mnemonics_memory_aids.concept: Compatibility of twist in multi-cell sections
mnemonics_memory_aids.context: Remind yourself that all cells in a cross-section share the same d\theta/dz.

flashcards.front: What is the relation between torque T, cell area A, and mean shear flow q for a single closed thin-walled cell?
flashcards.back: For a single closed thin-walled cell under Saint-Venant torsion: $T = 2 A q$, where A is the cell area and q is the (approximately uniform) shear flow.

flashcards.front: In a multi-cell thin-walled section, why is the problem statically indeterminate?
flashcards.back: Because the number of unknown cell shear flows exceeds the number of equilibrium equations. Additional equations come from compatibility of equal twist (d\theta/dz) for all cells.

flashcards.front: How is the total torque shared between two cells of areas A1 and A2 with circulating flows q1 and q2?
flashcards.back: Each cell carries torque $T_1 = 2 A_1 q_1$ and $T_2 = 2 A_2 q_2$. The total applied torque is $T = T_1 + T_2 = 2 A_1 q_1 + 2 A_2 q_2$.

flashcards.front: What extra condition must be applied in multi-cell torsion problems besides torque equilibrium?
flashcards.back: Compatibility of twist: the rate of twist $d\theta/dz$ must be the same for all cells in a given cross-section.

real_world_context.application: Wing box torsion under aerodynamic loads
real_world_context.industry_example: In a transport aircraft wing, distributed lift and engine thrust create a net torque on the wing box. The front and rear spars plus upper and lower skins form multi-cell sections that share this torque.
real_world_context.why_it_matters: Incorrect estimation of shear flow distribution can lead to undersized skins or spars, causing fatigue cracks or structural failure.

exam_strategy.triage_tip: Recognize it as a standard two-cell torsion problem. If you recall T = 2Aq and equal twist, you can set up two quick equations and solve for x/y without computing full numeric values.
exam_strategy.guessing_heuristic: If stuck, reason that the smaller cell usually carries slightly less torque per unit shear flow; expect x < y, so x/y < 1 but not extremely small (around 0.5–0.8).
exam_strategy.time_management: Allocate about 3–4 minutes. If equations become messy, focus on eliminating variables to get the ratio directly.

search_keywords: aircraft wing box shear flow Megson example

two cell box beam torque distribution

alternative_methods.name: Matrix method for multi-cell torsion
alternative_methods.description: Formulate the problem in matrix form with unknown cell shear flows and use a stiffness-like matrix relating torque and twist. Solve the linear system using standard matrix techniques.
alternative_methods.pros_cons: Pros: Systematic and scalable to many cells; easy to implement in software. Cons: Overkill for simple two-cell exam problems; more setup time by hand.
alternative_methods.when_to_use: Useful for complex cross-sections with many cells or when writing a small program to analyze wing boxes.

connections_to_other_subjects.Flight Mechanics: Wing torsional stiffness affects aeroelastic phenomena like divergence and control reversal.
connections_to_other_subjects.Aeroelasticity: Shear flow distribution and torsional rigidity are key inputs to aeroelastic stability analyses.
connections_to_other_subjects.Finite Element Methods: Multi-cell torsion theory provides validation cases for shell and beam finite element models.

deeper_dive_topics: Shear center of multi-cell thin-walled sections
Warping torsion and non-uniform torsion in open and closed sections
Aeroelastic divergence of wings due to insufficient torsional stiffness

syllabus_mapping.gate_subsection: Thin-walled structures; shear flow in open and closed sections; torsion of multi-cell beams
syllabus_mapping.feedback_for_syllabus_design: Excellent conceptual and computational test of thin-walled multi-cell torsion, directly aligned with aircraft structures syllabus.

rag_quality.notes: RAG provided general multi-cell torsion examples and structural idealization discussions from Megson, which support the conceptual method (T = 2Aq and equal twist). However, it did not contain this exact GATE problem or explicit x/y derivation, so internal knowledge was used to connect the theory to the specific question.

future_questions_potential: Ask for the absolute values of x and y given wall thicknesses and material shear modulus, requiring full twist compatibility calculation.
Extend to three-cell wing box and ask for torque share in each cell.
Combine torsion with vertical shear to find combined shear flow distribution and locate the shear center.

response_json.subject: Aerospace Engineering
response_json.question_text: The idealized cross section of a thin-walled wing box structure shown in the figure is subjected to anticlockwise torque of 10 kNm. The corresponding shear-flow distribution under this loading condition is shown in the figure. The area of each cell is A1 = 300x10^3 mm^2 and A2 = 250x10^3 mm^2. The ratio of the unknowns x/y is given by ________ (in three decimal places).
